What is p5.js?

A JavaScript library for creative coding
Makes coding accessible for artists, designers, and beginners
Based on Processing programming language
Runs in web browsers

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
createCanvas()
function setup() {
  createCanvas(800, 600);    // width, height in pixels
  createCanvas(400, 400);    // square canvas
}


Creates the drawing canvas
First parameter: width in pixels
Second parameter: height in pixels
Usually called once in setup()
Default size: 100x100 if not specified

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
Drawing Basic Shapes: rect()
function setup() {
  createCanvas(400, 400);
  rect(50, 50, 100, 75);     // x, y, width, height
  rect(200, 200, 80, 80);    // square rectangle
}


rect(x, y, width, height)
x, y: top-left corner position
width: horizontal size
height: vertical size
Coordinate system: (0,0) is top-left corner

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
Drawing Lines: line()
function setup() {
  createCanvas(400, 400);
  line(0, 0, 100, 100);      // x1, y1, x2, y2
  line(50, 200, 350, 50);    // diagonal line
}


line(x1, y1, x2, y2)
Draws a straight line between two points
x1, y1: starting point
x2, y2: ending point
Line thickness controlled by strokeWeight()

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
Understanding RGB Colors
fill(255, 0, 0);     // Pure Red
fill(0, 255, 0);     // Pure Green  
fill(0, 0, 255);     // Pure Blue
fill(255, 255, 0);   // Yellow (Red + Green)
fill(255, 0, 255);   // Magenta (Red + Blue)
fill(0, 255, 255);   // Cyan (Green + Blue)
fill(255, 255, 255); // White
fill(0, 0, 0);       // Black
fill(128, 128, 128); // Gray


Red, Green, Blue values
Each value: 0-255 (0 = none, 255 = maximum)
Mix values to create any color

title: Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
RGB Color System Explained


Additive color model (light-based)
Each pixel has red, green, and blue light components
0: No light (dark/off)
255: Maximum light (brightest)
Combining all three at 255 = white light
All three at 0 = no light (black)

title: Basic p5.js Commands
Syllabus, Shapes, and Colors
text:
Key Takeaways


setup(): runs once, initialize your program
draw(): runs continuously, create animations
createCanvas(): set your drawing area size
rect() and line(): basic drawing commands
fill() and stroke(): control colors
rectMode(): change how rectangles are positioned
RGB: mix red, green, blue values (0-255) for any color

title: Variables & Conventions
text:
Comments
Code comments are text in your code that your computer can‚Äôt see. They are great for muting code or explaining it.

let cx = width/2; // sets center to half canvas width
// let cx = width/4; // sets center to 1/4 canvas size

title: Variables & Conventions
text:
Console
The code console allows you to debug your code. You can see errors or log anything you wish with console.log()

title: Variables & Conventions
text:
Variables
Imagine variables as search and replace. Every time a variable appears, you could simply replace it with its value and the code would be the same.
The power here is that the value can VARY.
Yoda example

title: Variables & Conventions
P5.js Variables and Mouse Interaction
text:
What We‚Äôll Learn Today

Built-in mouse variables: mouseX, mouseY, mousePressed
Creating and using custom variables
The three steps of working with variables
Making interactive animations
Global vs local variables

title: P5.js Variables and Mouse Interaction
text:
Built-in Mouse Variables
P5.js provides several built-in variables for mouse interaction:

mouseX - Current horizontal position of mouse
mouseY - Current vertical position of mouse

mousePressed - Boolean: true when mouse button is pressed

These update automatically every frame!

title: P5.js Variables and Mouse Interaction
P5.js Variables and Mouse Interaction
text:
The Three Steps of Variables
1. Declare - Tell the program the variable exists
2. Initialize - Give it an initial value
3. Use - Put it to work in your code

P5.js Variables and Mouse Interaction
text:
Practice Exercise
Create a sketch that:

Has a circle that follows the mouse
Changes size when mouse is pressed
Changes color when mouse is released
Leaves a trail as it moves

Try combining mouseX, mouseY, mousePressed with your own variables!

title: P5.js Variables and Mouse Interaction
text:
Key Takeaways

mouseX, mouseY automatically track mouse position
mousePressed detects when mouse button is held down
Custom variables need: declare, initialize, use
Global variables are accessible throughout your program
Animation = changing variable values over time
Combine built-in and custom variables for rich interactions

title: P5.js Variables and Mouse Interaction
text:
Next Steps

Experiment with different variable types
Try incrementation operators (++, +=)
Explore other built-in variables (width, height, frameCount)
Create more complex interactive animations

Happy coding! üé®‚ú®

title: Variables & Conventions
text:
Built-in p5 Variables
P5.js provides several built-in variables for mouse interaction and animation:

mouseX - Current horizontal position of mouse
mouseY - Current vertical position of mouse

frameCount - The number of frames that have been displayed since the program started

These update automatically every frame!

title: Color
text:
Variables & Language
A variable is a symbol/placeholder for a value that may change. Computer variables and natural language might not be as different as you‚Äôd think.
Different words and symbols can have different meanings for different people. They may even change over time for an individual. In the same way, the value inside a variable can change.

Try not to judge yourself by what other students can do. It‚Äôs not a fair race if some started earlier than others.

title: Number Operations
text:
Incrementation Operators
Incrementation operators provide shorthand for changing variable values. They‚Äôre great for animation becuase they can change values over time.
The most common pattern in programming is increasing a variable by 1:
x = x + 1; // Traditional way
x++;       // Shorthand - increment by 1
x += 1;    // Also shorthand - increment by 1

title: Number Operations
text:
Common Incrementation Operators
x++;     // Increment by 1 (x = x + 1)
x--;     // Decrement by 1 (x = x - 1)
x += 5;  // Add 5 to x (x = x + 5)
x -= 3;  // Subtract 3 from x (x = x - 3)
x *= 2;  // Multiply x by 2 (x = x * 2)
x /= 4;  // Divide x by 4 (x = x / 4)
These operators make code cleaner and faster to write!

title: Number Operations
Number Operations
Number Operations
text:
The random() Function
The random() function generates random numbers, which can create variety and unpredictability in your sketches.
random();           // Random decimal between 0 and 1
random(10);         // Random decimal between 0 and 10
random(5, 15);      // Random decimal between 5 and 15
random([1,2,3,4]);  // Random item from array
// (arrays are also not on the next quiz)

title: Intentionally Random
text:
Jean Arp





Jean (Hans) Arp, Untitled (Collage with Squares Arranged according to the Law of Chance), 1916‚Äì17




While chance was undoubtedly the point of departure for this and other works in the series According to the Laws of Chance, the relatively ordered appearance of Arp‚Äôs collages suggest he did not fully relinquish control.

source: moma.org

title: Intentionally Random
text:
Math + Language Brainstorm
In your first project, you will:

use coding concepts from Week 1-4
use both math and language visually/conceptually. This prompt is open, as long as you can explain how you are using both.

The professor will set a timer. In your notebook, write and draw about a potential math + language project. Keep your pen moving the whole time. (You may also use a tablet)
